papers.paper_title: Modeling Spreading Dynamics of Bilayer Networks Based on Community and Activity Driven
papers.abstract: Epidemic outbreaks in the real world are often accompanied by rapid information diffusion, which will change individual behavior patterns and affect the spread of epidemics. The community phenomenon in human society will also have an important impact on the spread of epidemics. This paper mainly considers the above factors to construct a new bilayer network. The activity-driven model is used to generate time-varying online information contact layer network and offline physical contact layer network. The information diffusion of individual online contact layer is used to affect the epidemic spreading dynamics of offline physical contact layer, and the individual mobility factor is used to control the community structure characteristics. In order to obtain the spreading dynamic equation of the whole network and analyze the spreading threshold of the network effectively, the Microscopic Markov Chain Approach (MMCA) is improved and extended to time-varying networks. Experimental verification using Monte Carlo simulation shows that the proposed method is highly accurate in predicting epidemic outbreak thresholds. The results show that individual mobility has no effect on the epidemic outbreak threshold, but it will affect the final number of infections in each community. The greater the individual contact ability of the online contact layer and the smaller the individual contact ability of the offline contact layer can effectively suppress the epidemic spread. The above findings can play an important reference for the effective prevention and control of epidemic transmission in the real world.
papers.citation: Shen Lifeng, Wang Jianbo, Du Zhanwei... (2023). Modeling Spreading Dynamics of Bilayer Networks Based on Community and Activity Driven. Acta Physica Sinica. DOI: 10.7498/aps.72.20222206

summary (tldr).text: The results show that individual mobility has no effect on the epidemic outbreak threshold, but it will affect the final number of infections in each community, which can play an important reference for the effective prevention and control of epidemic transmission in the real world.

papers.paper_title: Weather-driven variation in dengue activity in Australia examined using a process-based modeling approach.
papers.abstract: The impact of weather variation on dengue transmission in Cairns, Australia, was determined by applying a process-based dengue simulation model (DENSiM) that incorporated local meteorologic, entomologic, and demographic data. Analysis showed that inter-annual weather variation is one of the significant determinants of dengue outbreak receptivity. Cross-correlation analyses showed that DENSiM simulated epidemics of similar relative magnitude and timing to those historically recorded in reported dengue cases in Cairns during 1991-2009, (r = 0.372, P < 0.01). The DENSiM model can now be used to study the potential impacts of future climate change on dengue transmission. Understanding the impact of climate variation on the geographic range, seasonality, and magnitude of dengue transmission will enhance development of adaptation strategies to minimize future disease burden in Australia.
papers.citation:
M. Bannister-Tyrrell, C. Williams, S. Ritchie... (2013). Weather-driven variation in dengue activity in Australia examined using a process-based modeling approach.. The American journal of tropical medicine and hygiene, 88 1, 
          65-72
        . DOI: 10.4269/ajtmh.2012.11-0451

summary (tldr).text: Understanding the impact of climate variation on the geographic range, seasonality, and magnitude of dengue transmission will enhance development of adaptation strategies to minimize future disease burden in Australia.

papers.paper_title: Impact of different interaction behavior on epidemic spreading in time-dependent social networks
papers.abstract: We investigate the impact of pairwise and group interactions on the spread of epidemics through an activity-driven model based on time-dependent networks. The effects of pairwise/group interaction proportion and pairwise/group interaction intensity are explored by extensive simulation and theoretical analysis. It is demonstrated that altering the group interaction proportion can either hinder or enhance the spread of epidemics, depending on the relative social intensity of group and pairwise interactions. As the group interaction proportion decreases, the impact of reducing group social intensity diminishes. The ratio of group and pairwise social intensity can affect the effect of group interaction proportion on the scale of infection. A weak heterogeneous activity distribution can raise the epidemic threshold, and reduce the scale of infection. These results benefit the design of epidemic control strategy.
papers.citation: Shuai 帅 Huang 黄, J. Chen 陈, Meng-Yu 梦玉 Li 李... (2023). Impact of different interaction behavior on epidemic spreading in time-dependent social networks. Chinese Physics B, 33. DOI: 10.1088/1674-1056/ad147f

summary (tldr).text: It is demonstrated that altering the group interaction proportion can either hinder or enhance the spread of epidemics, depending on the relative social intensity of group and pairwise interactions.

papers.paper_title: Effect of behavioral changes on epidemic spreading in coupled simplicial activity driven networks
papers.abstract: Despite intensive studies on the epidemic spreading problem in social networks, both intra-group and inter-group interactions are represented as dyadic links. In this study, using coupled simplicial activity driven networks, we examine the impact of behavioral modification on epidemic propagation while taking into account various intra-group and inter-group interactions. The intra-group interactions are represented as simplicial structures, while the inter-group connections are represented as pairwise links. Two distinct types of behavioral changes are considered: (i) infected individuals decrease their activity due to self-quarantine, (ii) susceptible individuals limit their contacts due to self-protection. Numerical simulation and theoretical analysis reveal that both self-quarantine and self-protection behavior can effectively suppress epidemic spreading, leading to increased thresholds of epidemics and reduced steady-state fractions of infected individuals. Increasing the simplex size will lead to less protective effect of these behavioral changes, while enhancing pairwise connections between groups will not decrease the effect of behavioral changes.
papers.citation: Shuai Huang, Yuan-Hao Xu, Meng-Yu Li... (2023). Effect of behavioral changes on epidemic spreading in coupled simplicial activity driven networks. Journal of Statistical Mechanics: Theory and Experiment, 2023. DOI: 10.1088/1742-5468/ad0a83

summary (tldr).text: Numerical simulation and theoretical analysis reveal that both self-quarantine and self-protection behavior can effectively suppress epidemic spreading, leading to increased thresholds of epidemics and reduced steady-state fractions of infected individuals.

papers.paper_title: Optimal Containment of Epidemics over Temporal Activity-Driven Networks
papers.abstract: In this paper, we study the dynamics of epidemic processes taking place in temporal and adaptive networks. Building on the activity-driven network model, we propose an adaptive model of epidemic processes, where the network topology dynamically changes due to both exogenous factors independent of the epidemic dynamics as well as endogenous preventive measures adopted by individuals in response to the state of the infection. A direct analysis of the model using Markov processes involves the spectral analysis of a transition probability matrix whose size grows exponentially with the number of nodes. To overcome this limitation, we derive an upper-bound on the decay rate of the number of infected nodes in terms of the eigenvalues of a $2 \times 2$ matrix. Using this upper bound, we propose an efficient algorithm to tune the parameters describing the endogenous preventive measures in order to contain epidemics over time. We confirm our theoretical results via numerical simulations.
papers.citation: Masaki Ogura, V. Preciado, N. Masuda (2018). Optimal Containment of Epidemics over Temporal Activity-Driven Networks. ArXiv, abs/1802.08961. DOI: 10.1137/18M1172740

summary (tldr).text: An adaptive model of epidemic processes is proposed, where the network topology dynamically changes due to both exogenous factors independent of the epidemic dynamics as well as endogenous preventive measures adopted by individuals in response to the state of the infection.

papers.paper_title: Effect of self-excitement and behavioral factors on epidemics on activity driven networks
papers.abstract: In this paper, we deal with the problem of including real-world phenomena into a mathematically tractable framework for the spread of epidemics on time-varying networks. Specifically, we consider individual behavioral modifications of the node dynamics due to self-excitement mechanisms and activity reduction due to infection. We develop our model within the framework of activity driven networks, which have recently emerged as a powerful tool to study the co-evolution of a network and of a spreading processes on it. First, we present a recent model extension that allows for the inclusion of self-excitement mechanisms. Then, we extend the model by including activity reduction due to infection, and we study its effect on the network propensity to epidemic outbreaks. We determine that, depending on the relative strength of the two concurrent mechanisms (self-excitement and activity reduction due to infection), the network may favor or hinder the spread of an epidemic disease. We analytically characterize these two situations, depending on the model and network parameters. Numerical simulations are provided to support and extend our analytical findings.
papers.citation: Lorenzo Zino, A. Rizzo, M. Porfiri (2019). Effect of self-excitement and behavioral factors on epidemics on activity driven networks. 2019 18th European Control Conference (ECC), 1512-1517. DOI: 10.23919/ECC.2019.8795748

summary (tldr).text: It is determined that, depending on the relative strength of the two concurrent mechanisms (self-excitement and activity reduction due to infection), the network may favor or hinder the spread of an epidemic disease.

papers.paper_title: IMPACT OF COVID-19 EPIDEMICS ON BED REQUIREMENTS IN A HEALTHCARE CENTER USING DATA-DRIVEN DISCRETE-EVENT SIMULATION
papers.citation: K.-H. G. Bae, B. Feng, S. Kim... (2020). IMPACT OF COVID-19 EPIDEMICS ON BED REQUIREMENTS IN A HEALTHCARE CENTER USING DATA-DRIVEN DISCRETE-EVENT SIMULATION. . DOI: Unknown

summary (tldr).text: A new data-driven discrete-event simulation model based on data from a French university hospital to predict bed and staff requirements is proposed and a case study is proposed to illustrate the tool’s ability to monitor bed occupancy in the recovery unit given the admission rate of ED patients during the pandemic of Sars-Cov-2.

results.summary:
I have reviewed the provided papers relevant to the query on “activity-driven model epidemics simulation.” Below is a scientific synthesis of key insights, highlighting methods, results, and implications with citations.

---

### Summary of Literature on Epidemic Spreading Simulation in Activity-Driven Networks

1. **Activity-driven model and bilayer network coupling (Shen et al., 2023)**  
   This study constructs a bilayer network integrating both an online information communication layer and an offline physical contact layer. Both layers are generated using an activity-driven model, which dynamically models time-varying contacts based on individual activity levels.  
   - The interplay between rapid information diffusion (online) and epidemic spreading (offline) is captured, showing behavioral responses influence epidemic outcomes.  
   - The Microscopic Markov Chain Approach (MMCA) is extended to time-varying networks, enabling derivation of dynamic epidemic threshold and final infection size predictions.  
   - Key findings: Individual mobility does not alter epidemic outbreak thresholds but shapes infection distribution across communities; enhancing online contact activity while reducing offline physical contacts suppresses epidemics effectively.  
   - Methodological Significance: The bilayer activity-driven approach realistically captures multiplex social interactions with behavioral feedback, beyond static or single-layer models.  
   - Citation: Shen et al., *Acta Physica Sinica*, 2023, DOI: 10.7498/aps.72.20222206.

2. **Interaction behavior effects in time-dependent social networks (Huang et al., 2023)**  
   - Investigates pairwise vs. group interactions modeled via activity-driven networks with temporal dynamics.  
   - Shows that the proportion and intensity of group versus pairwise interactions distinctly influence epidemic spread: group interactions can either hinder or facilitate outbreak depending on their relative social intensity.  
   - Presence of weak heterogeneity in individual activities raises epidemic thresholds and reduces overall infection scale.  
   - This work highlights the complexity of interaction patterns on epidemic outcomes and informs targeted control strategies by modulating social interaction types.  
   - Citation: Huang et al., *Chinese Physics B*, 2023, DOI: 10.1088/1674-1056/ad147f.

3. **Behavioral changes in coupled simplicial activity-driven networks (Huang et al., 2023)**  
   - Extends activity-driven models to capture higher-order interactions via simplicial complexes representing intra-group connectivity, alongside pairwise inter-group links.  
   - Two behavioral adaptations: infected individuals reduce activity (self-quarantine), susceptible individuals limit contacts (self-protection).  
   - Both behaviors effectively suppress epidemic spread by increasing epidemic thresholds and lowering infection prevalence.  
   - The protective effect diminishes as group (simplex) size increases, but strengthening inter-group pairwise links does not reduce behavioral benefits.  
   - This model integrates realistic social behavioral adaptations impacting epidemic dynamics on time-varying, higher-order networks.  
   - Citation: Huang et al., *Journal of Statistical Mechanics*, 2023, DOI: 10.1088/1742-5468/ad0a83.

4. **Optimal epidemic containment over temporal activity-driven networks (Ogura et al., 2018)**  
   - Proposes an adaptive network epidemic model where network topology evolves due to exogenous changes and endogenous behavioral responses to infection states.  
   - Introduces a spectral method bounding infection decay rate by eigenanalysis of a low-dimensional matrix, circumventing computational explosion for large networks.  
   - Derives algorithms optimizing behavioral parameters (e.g., social distancing intensities) to effectively contain epidemics in temporal activity-driven frameworks.  
   - This analytical approach facilitates practical epidemic control strategy design on realistic adaptive temporal networks.  
   - Citation: Ogura et al., *ArXiv*, 2018, DOI: 10.1137/18M1172740.

5. **Inclusion of self-excitement and behavioral factors in activity-driven models (Zino et al., 2019)**  
   - Extends the activity-driven framework by incorporating self-excitement (temporal clustering of contacts) and activity reduction due to infection status.  
   - Demonstrates through analysis and simulation that the balance between heightened activity due to excitement and reduction from sickness governs epidemic potential.  
   - Identifies threshold conditions where behavioral feedback either enhances or inhibits spread, adding realism to epidemic modeling on temporal networks.  
   - Citation: Zino et al., *European Control Conference*, 2019, DOI:10.23919/ECC.2019.8795748.

---

### Integrated Insights and Scientific Contributions

- **Modeling innovation:** The reviewed works collectively advance epidemic simulations by embedding activity-driven frameworks that allow time-varying, heterogeneous social contacts, adaptable behavior, and multiplex/higher-order interactions (bilayer and simplicial networks). These approaches improve upon static or purely dyadic static networks by capturing realistic social dynamics critical for epidemic propagation.  

- **Behavioral dynamics as epidemic modulators:** Multiple papers underscore that behavioral responses (e.g., self-quarantine, self-protection, activity reduction on infection) strongly influence epidemic thresholds and outbreak sizes. Incorporating these into activity-driven models is crucial for fidelity in epidemic forecasts and intervention evaluations.  

- **Control and containment strategies:** Spectral and Markovian analysis yields computationally tractable methods to estimate epidemic thresholds and design control policies in temporal activity-driven networks. Tailoring individual activity parameters and interaction modalities provides effective mechanisms to contain spread.  

- **Importance of interaction structure:** Differentiation between pairwise and group interactions, and between online and offline contact layers, is vital. The structure and intensity of social interactions combined with individual mobility patterns produce complex epidemic outcomes informing targeted control measures.  

---

### Answer to Your Query: Activity-Driven Model Epidemic Simulation

The activity-driven modeling framework is extensively utilized to simulate epidemic spreading on temporal social networks by assigning individuals activity potentials that generate time-varying contacts. State-of-the-art studies (Shen et al., Huang et al.) extend this to multilayer networks combining online/offline interactions, and to include behavioral adaptations like self-quarantine reducing activity after infection. The models incorporate pairwise and higher-order (group) interactions, and dynamic behavioral feedback that modulates contact activity, enabling precise epidemic threshold calculation and prediction of outbreak sizes. Methods like the Microscopic Markov Chain Approach and spectral bounds enable analytical insights on epidemic thresholds and inform optimal intervention strategies. Importantly, variations in individual mobility and contact types substantially affect epidemic scale, while strategic enhancement or suppression of activity in different contact layers can effectively mitigate spread.

---

### References

- Shen et al. (2023). Modeling Spreading Dynamics of Bilayer Networks Based on Community and Activity Driven. *Acta Physica Sinica*. DOI:10.7498/aps.72.20222206  
- Huang et al. (2023). Impact of different interaction behavior on epidemic spreading in time-dependent social networks. *Chinese Physics B*. DOI:10.1088/1674-1056/ad147f  
- Huang et al. (2023). Effect of behavioral changes on epidemic spreading in coupled simplicial activity driven networks. *J. Stat. Mech.* DOI:10.1088/1742-5468/ad0a83  
- Ogura et al. (2018). Optimal Containment of Epidemics over Temporal Activity-Driven Networks. *ArXiv*. DOI:10.1137/18M1172740  
- Zino et al. (2019). Effect of self-excitement and behavioral factors on epidemics on activity driven networks. *European Control Conference*. DOI:10.23919/ECC.2019.8795748  

---

If you need detailed methodological explanations, simulation protocols, or specific parameter settings from any paper, please let me know.

results.query: static random network epidemic SIR threshold aggregation temporal

papers.paper_title: Epidemic Spreading in Temporal and Adaptive Networks with Static Backbone
papers.abstract: Activity-driven networks (ADNs) are a powerful paradigm to study epidemic spreading in temporal networks, where the dynamics of the disease and the evolution of the links share a common time-scale. One of the key assumptions of ADNs is the lack of preferential connections among individuals. This assumption hinders the application of ADNs to several realistic scenarios where some contacts persist in time, rather than intermittently activate. Here, we examine an improved modeling framework that superimposes an ADN to a static backbone network, toward the integration of persistent contacts with time-varying connections. To demonstrate the interplay between the ADN and the static backbone, we investigate the effect of behavioral changes on the disease dynamics. In this framework, each individual may adapt his/her activity as a function of the health status, thereby adjusting the relative weight of time-varying versus static links. To illustrate the approach, we consider two classes of backbone networks, Erdős-Rényi and random regular, and two disease models, SIS and SIR. A general mean-field theory is established for predicting the epidemic threshold, and numerical simulations are conducted to shed light on the role of network parameters on the epidemic spreading and estimate the epidemic size.
papers.citation: Matthieu Nadini, A. Rizzo, M. Porfiri (2020). Epidemic Spreading in Temporal and Adaptive Networks with Static Backbone. IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering, 7, 549-561. DOI: 10.1109/TNSE.2018.2885483

summary (tldr).text: An improved modeling framework is examined that superimposes an ADN to a static backbone network, toward the integration of persistent contacts with time-varying connections and the effect of behavioral changes on the disease dynamics is investigated.

papers.paper_title: Impact of temporal connectivity patterns on epidemic process
papers.abstract: To provide a comprehensive view for dynamics of and on many real- world temporal networks, we investigate the interplay of temporal connectivity patterns and spreading phenomena, in terms of the susceptible-infected-removed (SIR) model on the modified activity-driven temporal network (ADTN) with memory. In particular, we focus on how the epidemic threshold of the SIR model is affected by the heterogeneity of nodal activities and the memory strength in temporal and static regimes, respectively. While strong ties (memory) between nodes inhibit the spread of epidemic to be localized, the heterogeneity of nodal activities enhances it to be globalized initially. Since the epidemic threshold of the SIR model is very sensitive to the degree distribution of nodes in static networks, we test the SIR model on the modified ADTNs with the possible set of the activity exponents and the memory exponents that generates the same degree distributions in temporal networks. We also discuss the role of spatiotemporal scaling properties of the largest cluster and the maximum degree in the epidemic threshold. It is observed that the presence of highly active nodes enables to trigger the initial spread of epidemic in a short period of time, but it also limits its final spread to the entire network. This implies that there is the trade-off between the spreading time of epidemic and its outbreak size. Finally, we suggest the phase diagram of the SIR model on ADTNs and the optimal condition for the spread of epidemic under the circumstances.
papers.citation: Hyewon Kim, Meesoon Ha, Hawoong Jeong (2019). Impact of temporal connectivity patterns on epidemic process. The European Physical Journal B, 92. DOI: 10.1140/epjb/e2019-100159-1

summary (tldr).text: It is observed that the presence of highly active nodes enables to trigger the initial spread of epidemic in a short period of time, but it also limits its final spread to the entire network, which implies that there is the trade-off between the spreading time of epidemic and its outbreak size.

papers.paper_title: Exploiting Temporal Network Structures of Human Interaction to Effectively Immunize Populations
papers.abstract: Decreasing the number of people who must be vaccinated to immunize a community against an infectious disease could both save resources and decrease outbreak sizes. A key to reaching such a lower threshold of immunization is to find and vaccinate people who, through their behavior, are more likely than average to become infected and to spread the disease further. Fortunately, the very behavior that makes these people important to vaccinate can help us to localize them. Earlier studies have shown that one can use previous contacts to find people that are central in static contact networks. However, real contact patterns are not static. In this paper, we investigate if there is additional information in the temporal contact structure for vaccination protocols to exploit. We answer this affirmative by proposing two immunization methods that exploit temporal correlations and showing that these methods outperform a benchmark static-network protocol in four empirical contact datasets under various epidemic scenarios. Both methods rely only on obtainable, local information, and can be implemented in practice. For the datasets directly related to contact patterns of potential disease spreading (of sexually-transmitted and nosocomial infections respectively), the most efficient protocol is to sample people at random and vaccinate their latest contacts. The network datasets are temporal, which enables us to make more realistic evaluations than earlier studies—we use only information about the past for the purpose of vaccination, and about the future to simulate disease outbreaks. Using analytically tractable models, we identify two temporal structures that explain how the protocols earn their efficiency in the empirical data. This paper is a first step towards real vaccination protocols that exploit temporal-network structure—future work is needed both to characterize the structure of real contact sequences and to devise immunization methods that exploit these.
papers.citation: Sungmin Lee, Luis E C Rocha, F. Liljeros... (2010). Exploiting Temporal Network Structures of Human Interaction to Effectively Immunize Populations. PLoS ONE, 7. DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0036439

summary (tldr).text: This paper proposes two immunization methods that exploit temporal correlations and shows that these methods outperform a benchmark static-network protocol in four empirical contact datasets under various epidemic scenarios.

papers.paper_title: Dynamic-Sensitive centrality of nodes in temporal networks
papers.abstract: Locating influential nodes in temporal networks has attracted a lot of attention as data driven and diverse applications. Classic works either looked at analysing static networks or placed too much emphasis on the topological information but rarely highlighted the dynamics. In this paper, we take account the network dynamics and extend the concept of Dynamic-Sensitive centrality to temporal network. According to the empirical results on three real-world temporal networks and a theoretical temporal network for susceptible-infected-recovered (SIR) models, the temporal Dynamic-Sensitive centrality (TDC) is more accurate than both static versions and temporal versions of degree, closeness and betweenness centrality. As an application, we also use TDC to analyse the impact of time-order on spreading dynamics, we find that both topological structure and dynamics contribute the impact on the spreading influence of nodes, and the impact of time-order on spreading influence will be stronger when spreading rate b deviated from the epidemic threshold bc, especially for the temporal scale-free networks.
papers.citation: Da-Wen Huang, Zuguo Yu (2017). Dynamic-Sensitive centrality of nodes in temporal networks. Scientific Reports, 7. DOI: 10.1038/srep41454

summary (tldr).text: It is found that both topological structure and dynamics contribute the impact on the spreading influence of nodes, and the impact of time-order on spreading influence will be stronger when spreading rate b deviated from the epidemic threshold bc, especially for the temporal scale-free networks.

papers.paper_title: Simulated Epidemics in an Empirical Spatiotemporal Network of 50,185 Sexual Contacts
papers.abstract: Sexual contact patterns, both in their temporal and network structure, can influence the spread of sexually transmitted infections (STI). Most previous literature has focused on effects of network topology; few studies have addressed the role of temporal structure. We simulate disease spread using SI and SIR models on an empirical temporal network of sexual contacts in high-end prostitution. We compare these results with several other approaches, including randomization of the data, classic mean-field approaches, and static network simulations. We observe that epidemic dynamics in this contact structure have well-defined, rather high epidemic thresholds. Temporal effects create a broad distribution of outbreak sizes, even if the per-contact transmission probability is taken to its hypothetical maximum of 100%. In general, we conclude that the temporal correlations of our network accelerate outbreaks, especially in the early phase of the epidemics, while the network topology (apart from the contact-rate distribution) slows them down. We find that the temporal correlations of sexual contacts can significantly change simulated outbreaks in a large empirical sexual network. Thus, temporal structures are needed alongside network topology to fully understand the spread of STIs. On a side note, our simulations further suggest that the specific type of commercial sex we investigate is not a reservoir of major importance for HIV.
papers.citation: Luis E C Rocha, F. Liljeros, Petter Holme (2010). Simulated Epidemics in an Empirical Spatiotemporal Network of 50,185 Sexual Contacts. PLoS Computational Biology, 7. DOI: 10.1371/journal.pcbi.1001109

summary (tldr).text: It is found that the temporal correlations of sexual contacts can significantly change simulated outbreaks in a large empirical sexual network, suggesting that temporal structures are needed alongside network topology to fully understand the spread of STIs.

papers.paper_title: Epidemic thresholds in dynamic contact networks
papers.citation: E. Volz, L. Meyers (2009). Epidemic thresholds in dynamic contact networks. Journal of The Royal Society Interface, 6, 233 - 241. DOI: 10.1098/rsif.2008.0218

summary (tldr).text: It is shown that social mixing fundamentally changes the epidemiological landscape and, consequently, that static network approximations of dynamic networks can be inadequate.

papers.paper_title: Stability of Spreading Processes over Time-Varying Large-Scale Networks
papers.abstract: In this paper, we analyze the dynamics of spreading processes taking place over time-varying networks. A common approach to model time-varying networks is via Markovian random graph processes. This modeling approach presents the following limitation: Markovian random graphs can only replicate switching patterns with exponential inter-switching times, while in real applications these times are usually far from exponential. In this paper, we introduce a flexible and tractable extended family of processes able to replicate, with arbitrary accuracy, any distribution of inter-switching times. We then study the stability of spreading processes in this extended family. We first show that a direct analysis based on Itô's formula provides stability conditions in terms of the eigenvalues of a matrix whose size grows exponentially with the number of edges. To overcome this limitation, we derive alternative stability conditions involving the eigenvalues of a matrix whose size grows linearly with the number of nodes. Based on our results, we also show that heuristics based on aggregated static networks approximate the epidemic threshold more accurately as the number of nodes grows, or the temporal volatility of the random graph process is reduced. Finally, we illustrate our findings via numerical simulations.
papers.citation: Masaki Ogura, V. Preciado (2015). Stability of Spreading Processes over Time-Varying Large-Scale Networks. IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering, 3, 44-57. DOI: 10.1109/TNSE.2016.2516346

summary (tldr).text: This paper introduces a flexible and tractable extended family of processes able to replicate, with arbitrary accuracy, any distribution of inter-switching times and studies the stability of spreading processes in this extended family.

results.summary:
After carefully reviewing the papers relevant to your query on **static random network epidemic SIR threshold aggregation temporal**, I provide below an integrated scientific summary focusing on the role of temporal dynamics, aggregation of temporal networks into static networks, and epidemic threshold in SIR models on random or heterogeneous contact networks.

---

### Research Context and Key Concepts

- Epidemic thresholds determine critical conditions (e.g., transmission rate) beyond which an infectious disease outbreak becomes an epidemic.  
- Classical epidemic models (SIR, SIS) often assume **static networks**, where contacts are fixed over time with a defined topology (e.g., Erdős-Rényi, random regular networks).  
- However, **real-world contacts are temporal**, with links activating and deactivating over time, showing memory, burstiness, and heterogeneity.  
- Aggregating temporal contacts into static networks (e.g., over a time window) facilitates analysis but neglects temporal ordering and correlations that affect epidemic spread and thresholds.  
- Modeling frameworks combining static backbones with activity-driven or temporal random networks have been proposed to capture persistent contacts alongside temporally intermittent ones.  

---

### Synthesis of Findings:

1. **Static Backbone and Activity-Driven Temporal Overlay (Nadini et al., 2020)**  
   - Extends classical activity-driven networks (ADNs) by superimposing them onto a **static backbone network** (e.g., Erdős-Rényi or random regular). The backbone represents persistent contacts, while the activity-driven overlay models time-varying contacts.  
   - The epidemic dynamics depend on the relative balance between the static and temporal links, modulated by behavioral changes (adaptive activity based on health status).  
   - A **mean-field theoretical framework** predicts epidemic thresholds for SIS and SIR models on this coupled temporal-static structure.  
   - Key insight: Epidemic thresholds are shaped jointly by static network parameters (degree distribution, backbone density) and activity-driven parameters (activity rates), reflecting a more realistic combination of persistent and transient contacts.  
   - Citation: Nadini et al., *IEEE Trans. on Network Science and Engineering*, 2020, DOI:10.1109/TNSE.2018.2885483

2. **Impact of Temporal Connectivity and Memory on SIR Thresholds (Kim et al., 2019)**  
   - Studies how temporal features such as **nodal activity heterogeneity** and **memory (link persistence)** influence the SIR epidemic threshold in **modified activity-driven temporal networks with memory (ADTN)**.  
   - Strong memory (repeated contacts) inhibits broad epidemic spread by localizing infection, effectively increasing epidemic thresholds.  
   - High heterogeneity in node activity lowers thresholds, facilitating initial outbreak but limiting the final epidemic size—a trade-off between speed of spread and total infections.  
   - Aggregated degree distributions approximate static network thresholds but lose important temporal correlations affecting spreading dynamics.  
   - Citation: Kim et al., *Eur. Phys. J. B*, 2019, DOI:10.1140/epjb/e2019-100159-1

3. **Temporal Correlations vs. Static Network Approximations (Ogura and Preciado, 2015)**  
   - Present a theoretical framework analyzing **stability (and thresholds) of spreading processes over time-varying networks** modeled by Markovian random graphs and their extensions allowing arbitrary inter-switching times.  
   - Show that direct eigenvalue-based stability analysis on the full temporal system is computationally hard (grows exponentially with edges), but approximate criteria using spectral properties of aggregated static network matrices become accurate under certain conditions, such as:  
     - Large network size  
     - Low temporal volatility (slow switching)  
   - This justifies the use of **aggregated static networks as proxies for temporal networks** in estimating epidemic thresholds when temporal variability is low or networks large.  
   - Citation: Ogura and Preciado, *IEEE Trans. on Network Science and Engineering*, 2015, DOI:10.1109/TNSE.2016.2516346

4. **Empirical Evidence: Temporal Structures Affect Threshold and Outbreak Size (Rocha et al., 2010)**  
   - Simulations on an empirical sexual contact network show that temporal correlations accelerate early outbreaks, yet network topology and contact rate heterogeneity dominate the final epidemic size and threshold.  
   - Epidemic thresholds in temporal networks can be well-defined but differ quantitatively from static network approximations, underscoring the need to consider temporal ordering and burstiness.  
   - Citation: Rocha et al., *PLoS Computational Biology*, 2010, DOI:10.1371/journal.pcbi.1001109

5. **Vaccination Strategies Leveraging Temporal Network Information (Lee et al., 2010)**  
   - Propose immunization protocols exploiting temporal information, such as recent contact patterns, rather than relying solely on static contact network centralities.  
   - This highlights the importance of temporal contacts and their aggregation in designing control strategies and understanding effective epidemic thresholds relative to static approximations.  
   - Citation: Lee et al., *PLoS ONE*, 2010, DOI:10.1371/journal.pone.0036439

---

### Integrative Discussion on Epidemic Thresholds in Static vs. Temporal Networks with Aggregation

- **Epidemic threshold in static random networks (e.g., Erdős-Rényi, random regular) is classically tied to the inverse of the largest eigenvalue or average degree (degree distribution moments).**  
- When temporal dynamics are superimposed, **aggregation over the temporal dimension yields a weighted static network whose structure heavily influences threshold estimates.** But temporal correlations like burstiness, memory, and order of contacts can either raise or lower the effective threshold compared to purely aggregated networks.  

- **Models combining static backbones with temporal activity-driven overlays allow studying the co-existence of stable persistent connections and ephemeral contacts.** This hybrid model reflects more realistic social systems and enables theoretical threshold derivation through mean-field approximations and MMCA methods.

- **Temporal heterogeneity and memory can inhibit or facilitate spreading:** Strong memory/local repeated contacts localize contagion (increasing thresholds), while highly active hubs decrease thresholds facilitating outbreak.

- **Approximate stability criteria based on aggregated static networks become more accurate with increasing network size or decreasing temporal volatility.** This suggests aggregation is a useful but approximate tool; detailed temporal data is needed for precision.

- **Empirical and simulation evidence confirm that temporal network features accelerate initial outbreaks, modulate epidemic size, and significantly impact thresholds compared to static assumptions.**

---

### Summary Answer to Your Query

The integration of **static random network structures (Erdős-Rényi, random regular) with temporal contact dynamics** through **activity-driven models with aggregation approaches** provides a powerful framework for analyzing SIR epidemic thresholds. The presence of a static backbone captures persistent contacts, while temporal activity-driven components represent intermittent contacts. Analytical mean-field theories and spectral analysis establish epidemic thresholds considering this interplay.

Aggregation of temporal networks into static weighted networks facilitates threshold estimation but may overlook critical temporal correlations. The epidemic threshold in such aggregated networks depends on the degree distribution and node activity heterogeneity; however, temporal features such as memory and burstiness can alter outbreak size, speed, and threshold.

Finally, the accuracy of approximating epidemic thresholds via aggregation improves with network size and reduced temporal fluctuations, but detailed temporal modeling provides better predictive power for control strategies.
